message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a recurrent pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness lasting at least 6 months. Blaming others for their own mistakes or misbehavior is one of the diagnostic criteria for oppositional defiant disorder. While staying out at night, fighting at school, and leaving seat during class may be associated with other behavioral disorders, they are not specifically indicative of oppositional defiant disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, and vindictiveness that lasts at least six months. Blaming others for his own misbehavior is consistent with this disorder. Staying out of home at nights despite restrictions may be more indicative of conduct disorder. Fights at school may also be indicative of conduct disorder but not necessarily oppositional defiant disorder. Frequently leaving his seat during class despite instructions by the teacher may indicate attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness lasting at least 6 months. Among the options, blaming others for his own misbehavior is an additional symptom commonly seen in patients with oppositional defiant disorder. Staying out of home at nights despite restrictions is more commonly seen in conduct disorder, while fights at school and frequently leaving his seat during class despite instructions by the teacher are symptoms commonly seen in attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness lasting at least 6 months, with symptoms often directed toward authority figures. Blaming others for his own misbehavior is a symptom of oppositional defiant disorder. Staying out of home at nights despite restrictions is a symptom of conduct disorder. Fights at school and frequently leaving his seat during class despite instructions by the teacher are symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Blaming others for his own misbehavior is a common symptom of oppositional defiant disorder. The other options are more indicative of conduct disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry or irritable behavior, vindictiveness and disobedience towards authority figures. Among the options, blaming others is the most likely symptom to present in a patient with oppositional defiant disorder. Staying out of home at night would be more indicative of conduct disorder, fights at school could also be a symptom of conduct disorder but not necessarily oppositional defiant disorder, and frequently leaving his seat during class despite instructions by the teacher suggests attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a persistent pattern of disobedient, defiant, and hostile behavior towards authority figures. Blaming others for one's own mistakes is a common symptom in patients with ODD. Staying out of home at night despite restrictions is more indicative of conduct disorder. Fights at school and frequently leaving one's seat during class despite instructions by the teacher are more indicative of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of negative, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behavior toward authority figures. Blaming others for their own misbehavior is a common symptom of oppositional defiant disorder. Staying out of home at nights despite restrictions, fights at school, and frequently leaving their seat during class despite instructions by the teacher are not necessarily symptoms of oppositional defiant disorder, although they may occur in some cases.

We refer to Mayo Clinic's website for help. Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) is a condition in which a child presents with an ongoing pattern of uncooperative, defiant, and hostile behavior toward authority figures. Among the options given, blaming others for his own misbehavior is the most commonly seen symptom in ODD. Staying out of home at nights despite restrictions is a symptom of conduct disorder. Fights at school and frequently leaving the seat during class despite instructions by the teacher are symptoms of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness. Blaming others for his own misbehavior is a common symptom in this disorder, whereas the other options are more likely to be seen in other behavioral disorders like conduct disorder.
